criteria: Understanding of the Formal Definition of a Limit
Knowledge of One-Sided Limits, Infinite Limits, and Limits at Infinity
descriptions: No understanding of the formal definition of a limit is demonstrated.
Demonstrates minimal understanding of the formal definition of a limit. Key components are missing or misunderstood.
Demonstrates a partial understanding of the formal definition of a limit but struggles to apply it correctly.
Demonstrates a satisfactory understanding of the formal definition of a limit and can apply it in simple cases.
Demonstrates a strong understanding of the formal definition of a limit and can apply it in most cases.
Demonstrates a comprehensive understanding of the formal definition of a limit and can apply it correctly in all cases.
No understanding of the graphical interpretation of limits is demonstrated.
Demonstrates minimal understanding of graphical interpretation of limits. Struggles to identify limits on a graph.
Demonstrates a partial understanding of graphical interpretation of limits, but makes frequent errors.
Demonstrates a satisfactory understanding of graphical interpretation of limits and can identify limits on basic graphs.
Demonstrates a strong understanding of graphical interpretation of limits and can accurately determine limits on complex graphs.
Demonstrates a comprehensive understanding of graphical interpretation of limits and can explain the behavior of functions near limits with precision.
No knowledge of one-sided limits, infinite limits, or limits at infinity is demonstrated.
Demonstrates minimal knowledge of one-sided limits, infinite limits, or limits at infinity. Concepts are largely undefined or incorrect.
Demonstrates a partial knowledge of one-sided limits, infinite limits, or limits at infinity. Can identify some, but struggles with application.
Demonstrates a satisfactory knowledge of one-sided limits, infinite limits, and limits at infinity and can apply them in straightforward problems.
Demonstrates a strong knowledge of one-sided limits, infinite limits, and limits at infinity and can solve most related problems.
Demonstrates a comprehensive knowledge of one-sided limits, infinite limits, and limits at infinity and can apply them in complex and nuanced situations.
No understanding of convergence and divergence is demonstrated.
Demonstrates minimal understanding of convergence and divergence. Terms are misused or not understood.
Demonstrates a partial understanding of convergence and divergence but struggles to differentiate between the two.
Demonstrates a satisfactory understanding of convergence and divergence and can identify them in simple functions.
Demonstrates a strong understanding of convergence and divergence and can determine convergence or divergence for most functions.
Demonstrates a comprehensive understanding of convergence and divergence and can rigorously prove convergence or divergence.
